NAACP Report of Executive Secretary, March 4th thru April 17th, 1964 : page 2

body.value:
2
Sustaining Donation Program Con't

distributed last year will be brought up to date for this year's solicitation. Copies of last year's financial report will be distributed to prospective donors.
Vll. EFFORTS TO SOLVE DISCRIMINATORY PROBLEMS INVOLVING BOARD OF EDUCATION:
A letter has been sent to the Board of Education seeking information as to the status on th terms of  negotiation	that took place after demonstrations last fall. Also included in the	the letter was a protest of low and discriminatory wages paid cafeteria workers following complaints to the NAACP. The reply to our letter was
completely unsatisfactory and so indicated in the second correspondence which also included threat of demonstrations should the terms agreed upon last fall not be met through negotiation.
Vlll. Protest OF PROGRAM ON CIVIL RIGHTS BILL:
A telegram of protest was sent to Television Station WMCT following a discussion of the Civil Rights Bill on Channel 5 by two local lawyers who presented only the dissenting	The telegram was followed by a letter - protest, copies of which were sent to all news medial the Justice Department, and the Federal Communications Commission. As a result we will be given equal time to present our views. On Sunday, April 12 and Willis will appear a WMCT for this purpose.
IX, ViBRANCH'S EFFORTS TOWARD PASAGE OF CIVIL RIGHTS BILL
Two thousand petitions, each having space for some  eighty signatures, have been printed and are being sent to churches, organizations (civic, fraternal, social), busitesses, schools, etc. We are requesting that each recipient have his associates sign two petitions (one for each Senator) and return them to the NAACP office. In addition those receiving the petitions are also being requested to have their associates write letters to our Senators asking	a to vote for the Civil Rights Bill.
HOTEL COMPLAINTS:
A letter has been sent to the president of the Hotel Association asking for a meeting to discuss areas where hotels have not completed the job of desegregation.
XI. INTERCOLLEGIATE CHAPTER:
The Non-Violent Committee of the Intercollegiate Chapter of the NAACP has for several Sundays visited churches in integrated groups. There have been no incidents except at Second Presbyterian Church where the students have been barred for three consecutive Sundays. Policemen have been on the scene, but no arrests have been made. Prior to last Sunday's efforts toward admittance, press releases were sent to	all news media.
